awd_titl_txt: Extending Max-Pressure Control for Traffic Network Operations
awd_abstract_narration:
Traffic signal timing-ways to distribute right of way at signalized intersections-can significantly affect vehicle flows and create delays in urban cities. This project develops a new adaptive method for signal timing (max-pressure control) through mathematical proof and experimental results. Max-pressure control uses vehicle queue length information to optimize signal timing. This research addresses key fundamental limitations with existing work that discourage implementation and limit the practical benefits. This project also includes a pilot deployment study by partnering with Hennepin County in Minnesota to evaluate potential benefits on their intersections. Finally, it will extend the mathematics to suggest alternative route choices to minimize total congestion, and maximizing passenger flow in ridesharing services such as Uber and Lyft. Mathematical knowledge gained from this project will be directly taught through graduate school courses and Ph.D. student mentoring. To improve public awareness of the studied problems, outreach activities will be conducted to K-12 students.

This project will introduce realistic traffic flow assumptions into existing store-and-forward queueing models, namely high-density restrictions on flow, queue spillback, and first-in-first-out behavior. Since max-pressure signal timing normally relies on sensors to estimate queue lengths, it will investigate alternative data sources to calculate queue pressure, i.e. road travel delays. During these tasks, this project will search for new Lyapunov functions and modify the max-pressure control to retain the maximum-stability results. Simulation results will be used to study the effects on congestion when users change their routes in response to new signal timings. The project will further investigate actual benefits by partnering with Hennepin County in Minnesota to perform microsimulation and a pilot deployment on their intersections. Finally, the project will extend the throughput-maximizing approach to system optimal dynamic traffic assignment and passenger service in mobility-on-demand by using queueing models for those problems. Essentially, this research will bring the attractive analytical properties of max-pressure control into a more accurate model to move towards effective implementation in urban cities to realize the benefits in practice. The intellectual challenges of successful Lyapunov-based proofs of maximum-stability are significant. In addition, applications of the max-pressure approach to other transportation engineering problems with similar modeling goals will broaden the impacts across the transportation field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Max-pressure control is a new approach to traffic signal timing from 2012 that is grounded in mathematical techniques for modeling and adapting to the inherent randomness that occurs around road intersections in terms of vehicle arrivals and turning movements. The main benefits of this technique are the mathematically proven maximum throughput properties for the entire network, suggesting that max-pressure control will be at least as effective as any alternative traffic signal timing as getting vehicles through the city to their destination. When originally proposed, max-pressure control was primarily a theoretical construct with limited applicability to the practical realities of traffic signal timing as it is implemented on roads. This project had two goals: first, moving towards integrating practical traffic signal design while retaining the mathematical properties that make max-pressure control, and second, exploring how max-pressure control techniques could be used for other transportation problems. 

Intellectual merits

Max-pressure control techniques are mathematically challenging to derive. They rely on modeling traffic flow around intersections for the entire road network as a Markov decision process (a type of stochastic model with control decisions), which introduces challenges in the formulation and in the necessity of balancing realism and mathematical simplicity. Unlike most work on Markov decision processes, the model is not solved computationally. Instead, an intuitive yet precise control policy is proposed and studied mathematically. Lyapunov drift techniques, which explore the average change in the entire system over a small time step, are used to create mathematical statements about the system behavior that correspond to proving maximum throughput. Studying these mathematical techniques by themselves are challenging, but meeting the goals of this project introduced additional complexity. Realistic traffic signal behaviors, like choosing phases according to a signal cycle or providing sufficient crossing time for pedestrians, significantly disrupt the max-pressure control model. Analyzing the model with existing mathematical techniques to create a control that both respects standard traffic signal behavior yet achieves maximum throughput was difficult but successful. Max-pressure control was also studied for ridesharing vehicle dispatch, and that required significant creativity to construct a mathematical model of ridesharing amenable to max-pressure analysis.

Broader impacts

The main goal of using max-pressure control for traffic signal timing is improving traffic signals itself. The project team worked with Hennepin County, MN to perform a detailed simulation-based comparison of how max-pressure control would perform compared to their current traffic signal timing, using the most realistic simulation tools. Performance gains were significant: although throughput remained similar due to a fixed travel demand, the throughput benefits translated into significant delay reductions of over 50%. Furthermore, unlike the arduous process of retiming traffic signals, essentially the same control with some minor parameter changes was used for all traffic signals to achieve those benefits. The project team further worked with Hennepin County to explore implementing max-pressure control on the actual traffic signal control hardware towards conducting experiments on public roads, which we hope will occur during future research. Ultimately, this project made major steps towards practical use of max-pressure control and its ability to reduce road traffic. Max-pressure control's adaptive nature is likely to lead to 2 types of benefits. In peak demand scenarios with high congestion, max-pressure control would get vehicles through the city faster and reduce congestion. In low demand scenarios, max-pressure control would adapt to observed traffic at the intersection.
